title: Is Plato's idea of 'reality' of essence again relevant; can we any better now know an ideal of a thing, or things, than he explored, or better challenge his ideas and ask better questions? - Quora

response.answer_text: Plato is a crazy bastard who believe that there is such a thing as absolute beauty because he fooled himself into believing that his definition of beauty is somehow better than other people’s definition. That’s why he parade what he find to be “beautiful” as the “true reality” rather than reality itself. Fact, beauty is a subjective thing. What you find beautiful isn’t the same as what other people find to be beautiful. It is all a matter of tastes. But when people disagree with Plato’s version of beauty, he down right tell them that they’re wrong. Reality is define as the world or the state of things as they actually exist as opposed to an idealistic or notional idea of them. Meaning that reality is about facts. Not about notions of beauty or bias distorted view of what something is. A tree falls down from the forest. Just because no one saw it falls doesn’t mean that it didn’t. That is reality. That is facts. The Mona Lisa is made out of paint and paper. The value it has are things that people gave it. In reality, it is simply a piece of paper with paint on it. That is reality. That is facts. Plato notion of reality is so far removed from what reality actually is that I’m surprise people are still learning about it today.

There are many other good philosophers who followed Plato and wrote their ideas of things. I believe the Bible teaches more truth than the philosophers. The philosophers came to teach bad men how to become good. While Jesus came to give bad people Life.
